questions.question: alert: 'Hello'
Which one of these will print to the browser console?
JavaScript is a strongly-typed language
JavaScript is a case-sensitive language
let message //receive from API
questions.explanation: Here the variable is declared but not given a value, making it undefined.

questions.question: let learn,to,code
questions.explanation: It looks odd, yes, but it's actually fine. Three separate varibles are declared but not given values.

questions.question: Which one of these is not a JavaScript reserved word?

const address = {
  street: '123 Rainbow',
  city: 'Las Vegas'
  state: 'NV'
}
questions.explanation: This is just standard object literal notation.

questions.given:
const name = 'Mickey'
name='Minnie'

console.log(name)
questions.question: Run the code and...
questions.explanation: You're not allowed to change the value of a variabled declared with const. This statement is a little misleading, as you can change the properties of an object or the elements in an array, for example.

questions.question:
let team = "New York Yankees"
let team = "San Diego Padres"
questions.explanation: A variable can be declared only once. Here, it's been declared twice, producing an error.

questions.question: let $ = 'Mickey'

questions.given:
const myName = "Mickey"
const MyName = "Mickey"
myName === Myname
questions.question: This code returns true
questions.explanation: Even though JavaScript is case-sensitive, and the two variables are separate variables, their values are the same — and so the code returns true.

questions.q1: Code written to provide an explanation or instruction, but which is not evaluated or displayed is called a
questions.explanation: A comment. There are both single- and multi-line versions of comments.

questions.given:
/*
Make sure the turbo-blaster is loaded
before engaging the laser macrifier.
*/
questions.explanation: Any of these would be correct: 'multi line, multi-line, multiple line, multiple-line'

questions.given: Multiply 5 times 7

questions.question: What operator will give you the remainder left from dividing one number by another?

questions.given: Raise 4 to the 3d power
Join two strings together to form a longer string
questions.explanation: The + operator is used both for addition and for joining strings — a process known as concatenation

questions.given: Provide the operator that will increment a variable by 1 after that variable has been evaluated.
questions.explanation: ++ (when used in this position) adds 1 to a number after it's been evaluated. This is referred to as a postfix operator.

questions.given: Provide the operator that will increment a variable by 1 before that variable has been evaluated.
questions.explanation: ++ (when used in this position) adds 1 to a number before it's been evaluated. This is referred to as a prefix operator.

questions.given: Provide the operator that will decrement a variable by 1 after that variable has been evaluated.
questions.explanation: -- (when used in this position) subtracts 1 from a number after it's been evaluated. This is referred to as a postfix operator.

questions.given: Provide the operator that will decrement a variable by 1 before that variable has been evaluated.
questions.explanation: -- (when used in this position) adds 1 to a number before it's been evaluated. This is referred to as a prefix operator.

questions.given: Provide the shortcut operator that will add 7 to x
questions.explanation: I refer to it as a shortcut operator because it's a shorter version of x = x + 7

questions.given:
Assume 
addCustomer
returns either 
true
or 
false
. Use an operator that converts Boolean (true|false) values into numbers: 0 if false, 1 if true.
questions.explanation: Another use for the plus operator: when used in this way, it automatically converts Boolean values into corresponding numeric ones.

questions.question: let a = b = c = 2 + 2
questions.explanation: Evaluation begins at the farthest right and works backwards, so the first operation adds 2 plus 2 to arrive at 4. That value is then assigned to the variable, c. Moving backwards one operation, the value of c (which is 4) is assigned to b. Then once again, back up and assign the value of b (4) to the variable, a.

questions.given:
Assume 
addCustomer
returns either 
true
or 
false
. Use an operator that converts Boolean (true|false) values into numbers: 0 if false, 1 if true.
questions.explanation: Another use for the plus operator: when used in this way, it automatically converts Boolean values into corresponding numeric ones.

questions.question:
Just as there is a 
+=
operator, there are also 
*=, -=
, and 
/=
operators.

To test for strict equality (both value and type), use the 
~=
operator.
questions.explanation: For strict equality, use the 'triple-equals' operator: ===

questions.question: Which one of these operators perform a not-equality check?
questions.explanation: For non-equality, use the '!==' operator. The ! is pronounced 'bang'.

questions.question: You should always end a statement with a semi-colon.
questions.explanation:
Most of the time, JavaScript can imply the semi-colon at a line break. There are rare exceptions to this, however -- especially in the case of functions that 
return
a value.

questions.question: Statements are syntax constructs and commands that perform actions.
Multiple statements can be placed on the same line if separated with a semi-colon
let customersAdded = 0 // total for this salesperson

questions.given:
let a = 5
let b = 10/5
console.assert(a === b)
questions.question:
You can use 
console.assert
to test the truth of assertions.
questions.explanation: This is a little-used function of the console object. You can think of it as a poor-man's test. However, be aware that assertions that are true will print nothing to the console; only false assertions will be displayed.

questions.question:
console.table
...
choices: counts the number of cells in an HTML table
displays data in a tabular format

questions.question:
In almost all cases, the use of 
let
or 
const
is preferable to 
var
when declaring variables.
questions.explanation:
Unless you have a very specific need for the behavior 
var
produces (and you'll know if you do), you're better off with either 
let
or 
const
.

questions.given:
let beginning = 42
let ending = "24"
console.log(beginning + ending)
questions.question: Prints 66 to the console
questions.explanation: Since "ending" is a string, the plus operator will be used in concatenation mode: the console will print out "4224"

questions.question: const 2dNotice = false
questions.explanation: JavaScript variables can't begin with a number

questions.question: const second notice = false
questions.explanation: JavaScript variables can't have a space in them

questions.question:
The 
null
value means "nothing" or "value unknown"
questions.explanation:
If you use 
null
, make sure you don't surround it in quotes. Doing so would turn the value into a string.

questions.question:
The 
undefined
value means "value has not been assigned"
questions.explanation:
If you use 
undefined
, make sure you don't surround it in quotes. Doing so would turn the value into a string.

questions.question:
let name = "Mickey"
let greeting = `Hello, ${name}`
questions.explanation:
Tick marks indicate a template string, in which JavaScript expressions can be interpreted when placed inside 
${
and 
}

questions.question: Because JavaScript is not a strongly-typed language, it has no concept of data types
questions.explanation: Even though JavaScript is a weakly-typed language, it still has data types.

questions.question: Which one of these is <em>not</am> a JavaScript data type?
questions.explanation: string, function, and map are all JavaScript data types. uri, on the other hand, is not.

questions.question: Which one of these is not a JavaScript data type?
questions.explanation: set, object, and number are all JavaScript data types. conditional, on the other hand, is not.

questions.q1: A data type that is a set of statements that performs a task or calculates a value is called a

questions.given: const catYears = 54/0
questions.question: This code will return what data type?
questions.explanation:
This is an odd one. Dividing by 0 returns 
Infinity
, which is actually a number.

questions.question: const x = NaN
questions.explanation:
NaN
, short for Not a Number, is usually encountered as the result of a mathematical operation that goes awry, but we can, in fact, set a variable to 
NaN
. Why someone would want to do this is a mystery.

questions.given: The largest value of a number data type is (2<sup>53</sup> - 1) which is 9007199254740991. To use an even larger value, append the value with...
questions.explanation:
This is a new data type in JavaScript: BigInt. To use it, append 
n
to the value.

questions.given: 'Mickey' / 7
questions.explanation:
You might think it would produce an error, but instead, we get 
NaN
— short for Not a Number

questions.given:
You want to find the data type of a variable, 
x
...
questions.explanation:
typeof
is followed by its operand. This operator is unusual in that the operand can be wrapped in parentheses — or not.

questions.question: A template literal (also called a template string allows interpolation of JavaScript within a string.
questions.explanation:
Template literals are surrounded by tick marks — 
``

questions.question: let msg = `Today is ${new Date()}`
questions.explanation: Template strings allow JavaScript interpolation within the string.

questions.question:
`let guestList = 'Guests:'
* John
* Wolfgang
* Esmerelda
`
questions.explanation: Not only is this valid, but template literals have the advantage that they respect white space (such as line breaks).

questions.question:
"let guestList = 'Guests:'
* John
* Wolfgang
* Esmerelda
"
questions.explanation: You can only split lines, as we're doing here, with string literals, not normal strings.

questions.given: You want to split a string across multiple lines with a normal string (not a string literal)...
questions.q1: Four score and seven years ago
questions.q2: our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation.
questions.explanation:
Use the back slash (
\
) when you want to use one of several special characters. This is known as escaping a character. In this case, the right answer is \n

questions.given:
You want to use double quotes within a string that has been created with double quotes — like this: "
Amadeus was referred to by his friends as \"Wolfie\"
questions.explanation:
Use the back slash (
\
) when you want to use one of several special characters. This is known as escaping a character. In this case, the right answer is \"

questions.question:
If you want to insert a tab character in a normal string (not a string template), you should use the escape code
\t
questions.explanation:
Use the back slash (
\
) when you want to use one of several special characters. This is known as escaping a character. In this case, the right answer is \t

questions.question: Which one of these is not a JavaScript data type?
questions.explanation:
Many languages have a 
char
data type. JavaScript does not.

questions.q1:
A data type that specifies whether something is 
true
or 
false
is a
questions.explanation:
Note that 
boolean
data type values can only be 
true
or 
false
. Also note the lack of quotes — these are not strings.

questions.given: let invited = "false"
questions.question:
invited
has a value of type, 
boolean
questions.explanation:
Putting 
false
in quotes makes this a 
string
data type. Boolean values do not allow quotes.

questions.given:
You want to "flip" the value of a boolean value — changing 
true
to 
false
or vice versa
questions.explanation:
Using the bang operator (
!
)in this way is a common idiom.

questions.given:
Comparisons of values always return a boolean value. Here, use an operator to see if 
x
is greater than 
y
.
